These Are the Top Ten Most Anticipated Museums Opening Around the World in 2026
New institutions dedicated to digital art, exploration, hip-hop, conservation and more are expected to welcome visitors this year
Visitors to the Smithsonian Institution have a lot to look forward to in 2026. The National Air and Space Museum will complete its multiyear renovation with the reopening of its remaining galleries on July 1, the National Museum of African American History and Culture marks its 10th anniversary with a block-party bash in September and the Hirshhorn‚Äôs revitalized Sculpture Garden reopens in October.
America commemorates its 250th birthday this year, and the Smithsonian museums are sharing in the semiquincentennial celebration with a range of exhibitions, festivities and reopenings. The historic carousel on the National Mall is scheduled to reopen to the public in time for D.C.‚Äôs Fourth of July anniversary party, and the Smithsonian Castle will pause its first major renovation in more than 50 years to reopen to the public from Memorial Day weekend through Labor Day. Along with a visitor‚Äôs center, caf√© and souvenir shop, the Castle will feature a special exhibition, ‚ÄúAmerican Aspirations,‚Äù showcasing artifacts reflecting America's journey, including abolitionist Harriet Tubman's hymnal. Another exhibition, ‚ÄúIn Pursuit of Life, Liberty & Happiness,‚Äù opens at the National Museum of American History on May 14 and highlights 250 objects that explore the ideals of the Declaration of Independence, such as the desk Thomas Jefferson used to write the Declaration of Independence and the oldest surviving American fighting ship. This year will also see the expansion of the annual Smithsonian Folklife Festival. Titled ‚ÄúOf the People: The Smithsonian Festival of Festivals,‚Äù this larger, multisite experience aims to explore festivals as a powerful tool of civic engagement and cultural exchange.
Around the globe, a range of new museums dedicated to everything from Aboriginal Australian people to hip-hop culture are scheduled to open. The world‚Äôs first museum of A.I. digital arts, Dataland in Los Angeles, is expected to welcome public visitors, as is the United Arab Emirates' Guggenheim Abu Dhabi, an enormous repository of modern and contemporary art. The opening of London‚Äôs Museum of Shakespeare has been delayed indefinitely, though‚Äîfingers crossed‚Äîit could happen this year.
Whether you‚Äôre looking to take on the role of a National Geographic explorer or marvel at a Picasso painting up-close in a converted Art Deco garage, these 10 museums will open new ways to experience, appreciate and understand the world around us.
The Lucas Museum of Narrative Art; Los Angeles
Nearly a decade in the making, the Lucas Museum of Narrative Art is finally set to open in L.A.‚Äôs Exposition Park on September 22. This brainchild of American filmmaker George Lucas and American businesswoman Mellody Hobson celebrates the universal language of visual storytelling and its ability to connect people. Situated on an 11-acre campus, the five-story, 300,000-square-foot building will feature 35 galleries and a permanent collection of over 40,000 works highlighting all forms of narrative art, including murals, sculpture, photography, posters, illustrations, animation cels and even magic-lantern slides (painted or photographed images on glass plates). Along with images by beloved illustrators like Norman Rockwell and Beatrix Potter, original comic strips by cartoonists such as Charles Schulz and Jack Kirby, and iconic works by painter Frida Kahlo and photographer Dorothea Lange, the museum will also showcase cinematic artifacts, including lightsabers and original costumes from Lucas‚Äô own Star Wars universe. Additional amenities include two on-site theaters, a restaurant and a retail store.
National Geographic Museum of Exploration; Washington, D.C.
Since 1888, the National Geographic Society has illuminated the wonders of our world through travel, science, education and storytelling. This summer, the new National Geographic Museum of Exploration will help bring these wonders to life, using cutting-edge technology, visual journeys and interactive experiences. Located at the Society's headquarters in D.C., the over-100,000-square-foot, sustainably built space will feature a ‚Äúwalking dark ride‚Äù that transports visitors to remote fieldwork expeditions and an interactive, large-scale digital installation of National Geographic‚Äôs magazine covers, beginning with its first issue in 1888. Visitors will be able to watch National Geographic films and exploration stories in an immersive, 400-seat theater and enjoy a nighttime courtyard experience that recreates six global ecosystems through life-size animal sculptures, touchable prints and audioscapes. Guests enter the museum through an 11-foot-tall yellow border that mimics the magazine‚Äôs iconic cover frame.
The museum‚Äôs inaugural exhibit, ‚ÄúPhoto Ark: Animals of Earth,‚Äù uses large-scale projections, touch interactives and images from the National Geographic Photo Ark, created and led by National Geographic Explorer Joel Sartore, to inspire protection of the world‚Äôs at-risk species.
UBS Digital Art Museum; Hamburg, Germany
Scheduled to open in the spring, the UBS Digital Art Museum will be Europe‚Äôs largest institution dedicated to digital and immersive art. Visitors will be treated to a fully integrated art experience, with approximately 70,000 square feet of exhibition space, soaring 39-foot-high ceilings and a permanent, multisensory work by international digital artist collective teamLab that occupies the entire museum. The exhibit, ‚ÄúteamLab Borderless,‚Äù consists of large-scale projections, interactive environments and everchanging narratives that forgo fixed boundaries and move throughout rooms, responding to each person‚Äôs movement, touch and physical presence. The museum is located within Hamburg‚Äôs HafenCity district, a massive waterfront development area known for its experimental architecture.
London Museum; London
The former Museum of London closed in December 2022 to reinvent itself as the soon-to-open London Museum. With easy access to public transit and significantly more space (290,000 square feet‚Äîroughly 6.6 acres‚Äîup from 183,000 square feet), this new iteration is scheduled to open in late 2026 in the city‚Äôs former Smithfield Market district. The London Museum aims to tell the story of Londoners‚Äîsuch as Winifred Herbert, who served as a cook during World War II, and fashion designer Mary Quant‚Äîacross 450,000 years, and will be one of the largest urban history collections in the world. It holds more than six million objects documenting the city‚Äôs history, including Roman mosaics, medieval armor, Victorian-era ironwork and street artist Banksy‚Äôs Piranhas, a painted box that appeared on a central London street in 2024. A unique feature of the new space will be a train line that allows passengers to peek inside the galleries as it passes.
The museum‚Äôs permanent galleries will occupy Smithfield‚Äôs abandoned Victorian General Market. The adjacent 1960s Poultry Market, opening in 2028, will house temporary exhibitions, collection stores and a learning center. The area has significant history: Smithfield once served as a Roman cemetery and hosted the boisterous Bartholomew Fair. It also played a prominent role in the novels of Londoner Charles Dickens, including Oliver Twist and Great Expectations.
MoN Takanawa: The Museum of Narratives; Tokyo
Tokyo‚Äôs MoN Takanawa: The Museum of Narratives blends traditional Japanese culture with cutting-edge technology. When it opens in March, this multilevel (six stories above ground, three below), experimental museum will combine traditional arts (like Kabuki) and food with manga, music and science, connecting the past with the future. New themes will be presented twice annually, beginning with the inaugural ‚ÄúLife as Culture,‚Äù which explores how everyday actions such as working, eating and resting create and sustain civilization.
The museum offers a unique mix of Japanese and futuristic aesthetics. Along with a restaurant and caf√©, MoN Takanawa also includes an underground theater immersed in digital LED panels and an experiential area for workshops. There‚Äôs a traditional tatami mat space for relaxing, an on-site library and three open-air terraces, including one where visitors can soak tired feet.
Dr. Jane's Dream: The Goodall Centre of Hope; Arusha, Tanzania
Jane Goodall died in October 2025, but the dreams of the groundbreaking English primatologist and environmental activist live on in Tanzania. Goodall spent her life connecting with the natural world, and Dr. Jane's Dream: The Goodall Centre of Hope inspires visitors to do the same. The space is scheduled to open in late October next to the Arusha Cultural Heritage Center, about 50 miles from Moshi, Mount Kilimanjaro‚Äôs gateway town. Brought together by a team of Disney alumni and African artists, Dr. Jane‚Äôs Dream will embody the scientist‚Äôs message of active hope through interactive exhibits, community-led conservation initiatives and screenings at an on-site theater. Visitors can listen to Goodall‚Äôs English translations of chimp cries at a stand-alone kiosk, see elaborately carved and painted tree trunks created by local Makonde artists and even ‚Äúfish‚Äù for food in a recreated termite mound using small probes, similar to how chimpanzees did in Goodall‚Äôs groundbreaking 1960 discovery.
Larrakia Cultural Centre; Northern Territory, Australia
Aboriginal Australian people have one of the oldest continuous living cultures on the planet. Australia‚Äôs Larrakia Cultural Centre pays homage to the Larrakia people‚Äî traditional owners of the land and sea that today comprise the country‚Äôs Greater Darwin Region, whose history and stories date back tens of thousands of years. At this multilevel space overlooking Darwin Harbor, visitors will be able to participate in hands-on painting and weaving workshops, observe Aboriginal music performances and learn the Larrakia language. The museum will display plenty of Larrakia treasures in its extensive exhibit space. These include sacred artifacts, such as glass spearheads and personal ornaments, that have been repatriated from international and Australian institutions.
The building features a bird-shaped roof that evokes a Larrakia ancestral being. Inside, there will be a restaurant showcasing local flavors, art studios and a retail shop, while outdoor areas will brim with native landscaping, an amphitheater with a sand performance area, and a saltwater ceremonial pond. It‚Äôs scheduled to open in October.
The Hip Hop Museum; Bronx, New York
The musical genre known as hip-hop came into the world in the 1970s. Known for its stylized rhythmic sounds, turntables and rapping, hip-hop became a cultural movement, influencing everything from fashion to technology. New York‚Äôs Hip Hop Museum, opening along the Harlem River waterfront this autumn, celebrates it all.
Situated just a couple of miles south of ‚Äúthe birthplace of hip-hop,‚Äù 1520 Sedgwick Avenue in the Bronx, the 55,000-square-foot museum will be home to 30,000 objects highlighting how hip-hop has impacted the world, making its way to concert arenas and influencing dance, politics, education and more.
Floor-to-ceiling displays will include items previously showcased at the museum‚Äôs temporary location in the Bronx Terminal Market, such as Dapper Dan custom-made jackets and Rappin‚Äô Max Robot, the first hip-hop comic book. Artist and designer Eric Orr created the four-issue series in 1986 with assistance from pop artist Keith Haring.
Center of Islamic Civilization; Tashkent, Uzbekistan
Although Uzbekistan is officially a secular state, Islam remains a key part of its culture and identity. Opening in March, the Center of Islamic Civilization in Tashkent will highlight the country‚Äôs contributions to Islam and serve as a global hub for studying and promoting the religion‚Äôs history, science and spiritual heritage. The three-story structure will feature more than 150,000 square feet of exhibit space and eight galleries showcasing Uzbekistan's Islamic heritage. They will include a collection of 114 Quranic manuscripts created by renowned rulers and calligraphers through the ages and a seventh-century Othman Quran (one of the oldest in the world). The center will also have interactive educational zones that utilize modern tech; for example, a series of ‚Äúliving portraits‚Äù of historical thinkers and scientists will answer visitors‚Äô questions using artificial intelligence. The institution touts a research center devoted to the study and preservation of Islam, labs for restoring ancient manuscripts and a 460-seat conference hall.
The architecture of the center blends Timurid-era Central Asian traditions (including intricate tilework and a 213-foot-tall blue dome) with modern design, putting Islam‚Äôs vast heritage on full display.
The Kanal-Centre Pompidou; Brussels, Belgium
Brussels' first museum dedicated to modern and contemporary art is scheduled to open November 28. The Kanal-Centre Pompidou will be one of Europe‚Äôs largest museums, with 430,000 square feet of space. This cultural hub is part of the landmark Centre Pompidou in Paris and emphasizes 21st-century Belgian art along with works from the main museum‚Äôs expansive collection. Visitors will be able to study pieces by pioneer of abstract art Wassily Kandinsky and Cubist Pablo Picasso, marvel at video installations such as artist Anthony McCall's light sculptures, and explore one of pop artist Roy Lichtenstein‚Äôs porcelain enamel-on-steel prints. Along with both permanent and temporary exhibitions, the museum will feature live music, dance and other performing arts, a library and a bakery. It‚Äôs all housed within Brussels‚Äô former Citro√´n garage, an Art Deco industrial space that has been transformed and repurposed.

Archaeologists Say They‚Äôve Detected the Largest Stand-Alone Ancient Roman Villa Ever Unearthed in Wales
The mansion‚Äôs foundations and floors are likely well-preserved, according to geophysical surveys. The discovery provides new insights into the Roman occupation in the region
Using ground-penetrating radar, researchers in south Wales have uncovered the foundations of an ancient Roman villa. The discovery illuminates the history of Roman occupation in the region, suggesting that it was more than just a military outpost for the empire.
The villa could be the largest known stand-alone structure of its kind to be found in Wales. It was discovered in Margam Country Park, located in the county of Neath Port Talbot, during geophysical surveys by the local company Terradat. The surveys were commissioned by the ArchaeoMargam project, a collaboration between nearby Swansea University‚Äôs Center for Heritage Research and Training, Neath Port Talbot Council and Margam Abbey Church.
The project aimed to uncover Margam‚Äôs pre-industrial heritage‚Äîand according to a statement from Swansea University, ‚Äúthe team struck gold.‚Äù
The massive villa‚Äôs foundations, located roughly three feet below the surface, stretch about 141 feet long, Langlands tells BBC News‚Äô Steffan Messenger. The ‚Äúreally impressive and prestigious‚Äù structure appears to have six main front rooms and two halls leading to eight rear rooms.
Southeast of the mansion is the footprint of another structure, which may have been a meeting hall or agricultural storage facility. The buildings appear to have been surrounded by a defensive enclosure, which covered an area of more than 25,000 square feet.
‚ÄúAlmost certainly you‚Äôve got a major local dignitary making themselves at home here,‚Äù Langlands explains to BBC News. ‚ÄúThis would have been quite a busy place‚Äîthe center of a big agricultural estate and lots of people coming and going.‚Äù
After the Romans invaded Britain in 43 C.E., they built structures such as military forts, roads, walls and baths. In Wales, most Roman ruins were built for the army, like the large Roman fortress and bath complex in nearby Caerleon. Stately Roman homes aren‚Äôt commonly found in Wales. However, the newly discovered foundations remind Langlands of sites found in places like Gloucestershire, Somerset and Dorset.
Quick fact: How long did the Romans control Britain?
The emperor Claudius invaded Britain in 43 C.E., and the Romans remained in power until around 410 C.E.
The newly discovered villa could demonstrate that Wales wasn‚Äôt just a ‚Äúkind of liminal borderland,‚Äù Langlands says to the New York Times‚Äô Stephen Castle. Instead, it may have been ‚Äújust as Roman as anywhere else we‚Äôve got in the heartlands of the province of Britannia.‚Äù
As the archaeologist explains in the statement, it‚Äôs too early to date the Margam villa or determine who built it. However, he tells the Guardian, ‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre in the fourth century‚Äîit really fits that kind of late Roman flourish that we see in the southwest of Britain.‚Äù
Because Margam has been a deer park since at least the Middle Ages, it has not been disturbed by agricultural ploughing. As such, researchers are hoping to find the villa to be well-preserved when they eventually excavate it, and the surveys indicate that much of the villa‚Äôs flooring and foundations are intact. The team has optimistically nicknamed the site ‚Äúthe Port Talbot Pompeii,‚Äù in reference to the Roman city that was covered in volcanic ash in 79 C.E.
‚ÄúWherever you get villas like this, they‚Äôre almost certainly surrounded by other edifices of the period,‚Äù Langlands says in a video from Swansea University. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve probably got trading centers here. We know we‚Äôve got the Roman roads here. There should be a bathhouse somewhere, and almost certainly there‚Äôll be other small Roman farmsteads.‚Äù
Researchers are keeping the exact location of the buried villa a secret to prevent outsiders from illegally digging on the site before the experts. The team shared its findings with the local community at Margam Abbey Church on January 17.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs out of this world,‚Äù Margaret Jones, a retired teacher from Port Talbot, tells BBC News. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm still a bit shellshocked at the thought that this place where I played, where my children and grandchildren have played‚Äîthat under our feet was this incredible house.‚Äù

A Robot Is Unraveling the Secrets of How Some Bats Bounce Sound Waves Off Leaves to Find Insect Prey
